threads.com:
/lit/ is for the discussion of literature, specifically books (fiction & non-fiction), short stories, poetry, creative writing, etc. If you want to discuss history, religion, or the humanities, go to /his/. If you want to discuss politics, go to /pol/. Philosophical discussion can go on either /lit/ or /his/, but those discussions of philosophy that take place on /lit/ should be based around specific philosophical works to which posters can refer.

Check the wiki, the catalog, and the archive before asking for advice or recommendations, and please refrain from starting new threads for questions that can be answered by a search engine.

/lit/ is a slow board! Please take the time to read what others have written, and try to make thoughtful, well-written posts of your own. Bump replies are not necessary.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21296489
Are your words Straussian? I'm being exposed to Strauss via Carl Schmitt's Concept of the Political. The edition I have (the common orange-covered one) has a collection of notes on Schmitt's work by Strauss, and from what I glean from the foreward and introduction of the work, as well as what I've read up on Schmitt (and now Strauss) on SEP, people seem to regard Strauss' critiques in those notes as pretty strong damning and conclusive.

To me though, his critique does not seem nearly as profound or as damaging to Schmitt's work as others apparently find it. But I don't know whether this is because I misunderstand Strauss (his notes and writings are very difficult to parse in a way that Schmitt's are not) or because of some other reason.

For example:
>We said that Schmitt undertakes the critique of liberalism in a liberal world; and we meant thereby that his critique of liberalism occurs in the horizon of liberalism; his unliberal tendency is restrained by the still unvanquished “systematics of liberal thought.” The critique introduced by Schmitt against liberalism can therefore be completed only if one succeeds in gaining a horizon beyond liberalism. In such a horizon Hobbes completed the foundation of liberalism.

What exactly does something not restrained by the "systematics of liberal thought" look like? What are those systematics? I understand Strauss is evaluating Schmitt towards his own ends, and that Strauss spent his life fascinated specifically by thinkers at the dawn of the liberal tradition (Hobbes, Machiavelli, etc), but for this to be a searching critique of Schmitt you'd have to be prepared as Strauss is to discard those systematics of liberal thought, right? But that seems to me to be missing the point; Schmitt's project is much "narrower" in scope than Strauss', and Schmitt is not interested in formulating a brand new, to use your words, comprehensive account of the Whole, which is exactly Strauss' project as I understand it right now. Am I wrong about that?

It seems to me that the analogs for what Strauss is working towards are those major traditions that were dominant before liberalism; religion. His talk of revelation and its importance further makes me think that.

Sorry for the scatterbrained post, I just woke up.

last_replies.com: Spenser is also an important influence upon just about EVERY English writer, Keats pays him literal homage in several semi-erotic poems (I think one is literally titled something like Ode in the style of Spenser or something like that) TS Eliot is influenced by Spenser, Virginia Woolf who had an Elizabethan fetish / fascination also mentions Spenser in her nonfiction essays. In terms of wider literature it is useful to read Spenser in comparison to Shakespeare, Elizabethan works in the Euphuistic style and I would also recommend some translations of the Spanish poet Gongora (Gongorisme is a comparable flamboyant style of concatenated intertwined metaphorical belletristic florescence). These are just some literary and critical observations I recall from reading WH Auden lectures on this period

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: If you read a lot of Shakespeare it becomes easier to understand Spenser, if you study carefully the etymology of words and how they change over time. You can often make some educated deductions as to meaning based upon etymology, use wiktionary to look up every word meaning. Any edition of Shakespeare will provide a glossary and you can begin to rapidly accumulate the meanings of all these words it is not too difficult.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
>In the Bible, God displays Behemot to Job, saying, "Behold Behemot, whom I have created with thee" ( Job, 40:10 ). Taking advantage of the ambiguity of the Hebrew original, Blake translates "with you" by from thee, "from you", indicating the unity of essence between man and monster: Behemot is at once a macrocosmic power and a latent force in the human soul. As for Leviathan, God asks, "Canst thou pull him with the hook, and bind his tongue with a rope?" ( Job, 40:21 ), making it evident that the force of revolt is in the tongue, while the power of Behemot, as stated in 40:11, resides in the womb. There could be no greater clarity in the contrast of a psychic power and a material power: Behemot is the massive weight of natural necessity, Leviathan is the diabolical, invisible infranature beneath the waters - the psychic world - that stirs with the tongue.

>The meaning Blake registers in these figures is not an "interpretation" in the negative sense that Susan Sontag gives to this word: it is, as all good sacred text reading should be, the direct translation of a universal symbolism. For Blake, although Behemot represents the whole of the forces obedient to God, and Leviathan the spirit of denial and rebellion, both are equally monsters, cosmic forces disproportionately superior to man, which move combat to each other on the scene of the world, but also within the human soul.

threads.com:
And behind him was a trail of death and destruction. Apollo held up the head of the monster he had slain, “I have saved you!” he exclaimed to the people, who exchanged glances and reasoned that despite all of the destruction due to the War that Apollo had perhaps indeed in fact maybe actually possibly ‘saved them’ from the monster. And so they began to cheer a little, some applauded, and as they emboldened each other the cheers and applause grew louder and louder.

Apollo basked in this. He had done Good.


Suddenly Jupiter appeared.

“APOLLO YOU’VE GONE AND DONE IT AGAIN,” Jupiter said, clouting Apollo across the ear, thunder rumbling as he did so, and he inquired next, “WHY DID YOU KILL MY SERVANT, THE CYCLOPS?”

Apollos mouth opened and closed, he was conflicted, “I did a Good thing!” he insisted, his spare hand clutching his bloodied-ear, “it was a monster that was causing harm!” and he explained to his reasoning, “I killed it, because nobody else could or would, in order to save these people from being hurt and aggravated by it,” and he motioned to the rabble of mortals, “therefore: I did a Good thing.”

Jupiter snorted, “YOU ARE A STUPID IDIOT,” he declared, “AND RATHER THAN ‘TELLING’ YOU ‘WHY’, I WILL ‘SHOW’ YOU ‘WHY’,” and he snatched up Apollo by the hair of his head and dragged him into the The Future, tossing him down a ravine, and flying down after him.


When Apollo had come back to life he found Jupiter crouched behind a particularly large boulder and that the two of them were overlooking a particularly steep mountain pass where, he could spy in the distance, a little cart and a few mortals were making their way along and towards them.

“DO YOU RECOGNIZE WHERE WE ARE?” whispered Jupiter.

Apollo of course did, “yes,” he said, “this is one of the paths that the cyclops used to attack people on; sometimes,” he went on, “when the villagers were very hungry in the winter they would try to venture down this path to find food, and the cyclops would leap out and pull off their arms and legs. I heard their pleas and visited them, and what they said was awful, so I did something about it.”

Jupiter nodded, “NOW,” and a pulsating bolt of energy materialized in his hand and took the form of a javelin, “SHALL I BLOW UP THESE MORTALS AND STOP THEM FROM GOING DOWN THIS PATH, OR SHALL I, FOR YOUR TUTELARY BENEFIT, ALLOW THEM TO GO DOWN THE PATH?”

1/3

This is just conjecture but I think very few people regard reading as a pleasurable activity. It's effectively painful for most to read books. So if they do, it has to be something of which the perceived practical benefit is obvious, unambiguous, and worthwhile. Just so happens that 95% of the perceived practical benefit of self-help isn't actually real. Consider exercise, most people exercise because they desire the benefits not because it's particularly enjoyable — without health or aesthetic benefits these people would have no reason to exercise. If you regard reading books like exercise, it's pretty obvious then that it doesn't make sense to read a fiction novel that doesn't have any obvious benefit unless you enjoy the activity of reading in itself. Basically none of these people are thinking this through though, it's not conscious reasoning.

The last days of the suicide kid

I can see myself now
after all these suicide days and nights,
being wheeled out of one of those sterile rest homes

by a subnormal and bored nurse
there I am sitting upright in my wheelchair
almost blind, eyes rolling backward into the dark part of my skull
looking
for the mercy of death
Isn’t it a lovely day, Mr. Bukowski
O, yeah, yeah
the children walk past and I don’t even exist
and lovely women walk by
with big hot hips
and warm buttocks and tight hot everything
praying to be loved
and I don’t even
exist
It’s the first sunlight we’ve had in 3 days,
Mr. Bukowski.
Oh, yeah, yeah.
there I am sitting upright in my wheelchair,
myself whiter than this sheet of paper,
bloodless,
brain gone, gamble gone, me, Bukowski,
gone
Isn’t it a lovely day, Mr. Bukowski
O, yeah, yeah pissing in my pajamas, slop drooling out of

2 young schoolboys run by—

after all the threats to do so
somebody else has committed suicide for me
at last.
the nurse stops the wheelchair, breaks a rose from a nearby bush,
puts it in my hand.
I don’t even know
what it is. it might as well be my pecker
for all the good

But this wilderness calls out to the 'civilized' men travelling through it because deep down they still have those primal instincts. The brutality of civilised man is portrayed in possibly worse terms than the tribes, the main difference is that it's systematic and has a false air of sophistication. Kurtz combines both these worlds to get the worst of both: in pursuit of money and efficiency for a huge company he becomes a tribal brute and ends up being too successful at what he does. >"Body am I, and soul"—so saith the child. And why should one not speak like children? But the awakened one, the knowing one, saith: "Body am I entirely, and nothing more; and soul is only the name of something in the body."

There's sentiments like this all over his works. He was a biological determinist, but his view of biology was very complex. He understood before psychoanalysis was even a thing that a "subject" consists of a "multiplicity of drives" and he'd be considered a racist today if people actually read him.

>>21295798
Per Nietzsche's own words, the ubermensch is one who represents "the antithetical character of existence most strongly, as its glory and sole justification" (WP 881), who has "the greatest multiplicity of drives, in the relatively greatest strength that can be endured" (WP 966), who bears "the greatest responsibility" and doesn't "collapse under it" (WP 975), who lives "beyond the rulers, freed from all bonds" (WP 998), and who "determines values and directs the will of millennia by giving direction to the highest natures" (WP 999).

Given this and the above, we're not just talking about an ideal "creator of values." "Values" are not metaphysical for Nietzsche. They're biological.

Zoilus, of course, is stand-in for 'any' gaudy freedman (imperial servants, newly minted ex-slaves, eunuchs, etc.) but as to the character 'of' the gaudy freedman can we, or could Marcus, expect anything more than what is displayed by him?

The obtaining of fat golden rings, the changing of clothes several times during a dinner, the purchasing of slaves with elongated penises, the theft of perfume boxes from a funeral, etc. Why, a former slave knows no better than to debase himself in such a manner and thinks nothing wrong with it - for he relishes in his new-found freedoms and turns freedoms to excess.

Does, then, the giver of shame and ridicule to the former slave constitute the only person around the former slave who actually 'cares'for the former slave, as like a father or mother might, if the former slave had ever possessed a father or a mother. I would say yes.

In spite of everything, Marcus Valerius Martialis and Zoilus the Freedman are secretly Best Friends.
